stage.name: IDEATING
stage.title: Problem / Solution Fit
stage.goal: Find a problem worth solving with people worth serving
stage.subtitle: Every great business starts with a problem worth solving

lines: Welcome to the War Room, entrepreneur.
Before we build anything, we need to find a problem worth solving.
Your success depends on how deeply you understand the pain you're trying to eliminate.
Let's see if you have what it takes to sense real opportunities...

stageEndCheck.convergenceLogic: AI ensures C1 and C2 fully assessed before stage completion

questions.questionText: What industry or market are you interested in?
questions.narrativeIntro: Let's start with the basics. Every entrepreneur needs a domain to operate in.
questions.helpText: Be as specific as possible. 'Healthcare' is too broad. 'Mental health apps for college students' is better.

rubric.description: Specific with personal rationale or research backing

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate the specificity of the industry/market selection. Look for clear boundaries, target audience hints, and research backing.

probeQuestion.questionText: That's quite broad. Can you narrow it down? Who specifically would you serve, and what's the specific problem area?
probeQuestion.narrativeIntro: I need you to think deeper. Broad markets mean broad competition and unfocused products.

questions.questionText: Who SPECIFICALLY is your target customer?
questions.narrativeIntro: Now let's get specific about WHO you're serving. The riches are in the niches.
questions.helpText: Include demographics (age, income, location) AND psychographics (values, behaviors, pain points). Example: 'Busy working parents aged 28-40 in urban areas, household income >$80K, who value convenience over cost and struggle with meal planning.'

rubric.description: Detailed persona with context, pain points, and buying triggers

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate customer definition. Look for specificity, understanding of customer context, pain points, and buying behavior.

challengeQuestion.questionText: If you try to serve everyone, you serve no one well. Who has the MOST URGENT need for your solution? Be specific.
challengeQuestion.narrativeIntro: Stop. This is one of the most common mistakes entrepreneurs make. Let me push you harder.

questions.questionText: What SPECIFIC problem are you solving?
questions.narrativeIntro: The foundation of every successful business is a problem people will PAY to solve.
questions.helpText:
Frame using Quality, Time, OR Cost:
• QUALITY: Is something broken/poor quality?
• TIME: Is something too slow?
• COST: Is something too expensive?

The best problems have clear, monetizable pain.

rubric.description: No clear problem identified, or solution-first thinking
Monetizable pain with evidence of willingness to pay

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate problem definition. Check for QTC framework, specificity, monetizability, and evidence of real customer pain.

futureImpact.stage0: Higher risk of building wrong product
futureImpact.stage1: Sales difficulty - customers don't see urgency
futureImpact.stage2: High churn - product doesn't solve real pain

questions.questionText: How did you identify this problem?
questions.narrativeIntro: Understanding HOW you found this problem tells me a lot about your entrepreneurial instincts.

options.text: Personal experience - I faced this problem myself

followUp.questionText: Have you validated that others have the same problem? How?
How many customers did you interview? What surprised you most?
Have you talked to REAL customers yet? What's stopping you?

options.text: Saw it as a trend-based opportunity
options.warning: RED FLAG: Trend-chasing without validation is high-risk

followUp.questionText: What EVIDENCE do you have that customers actually want this? Trends don't equal demand.

questions.questionText: Does a solution to this problem already exist?
questions.narrativeIntro: Competition isn't always bad. Let's see how you think about the competitive landscape.

options.insight: Good - competitors validate the market exists

options.warning: WARNING: No competitors often means no market. Be careful.

followUp.questionText: If this is such a big problem, why hasn't anyone solved it yet? What do you know that they don't?

consequence.reason: You need to research competitors before building

questions.questionText: Who are your main competitors? How are you different and BETTER?
questions.narrativeIntro: Knowing your competition isn't enough. You need a defensible advantage.

rubric.description: Understands why customers would choose them

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate competitive analysis. Check for named competitors, meaningful differentiation, defensibility, and customer choice understanding.

challengeQuestion.questionText: That differentiation sounds easy to copy. What's your DEFENSIBLE moat?
Price wars lead to thin margins. What else can you offer beyond lower prices?

questions.questionText: How much do you know about this industry?
questions.narrativeIntro: Domain expertise can be an advantage, but so can fresh perspectives. Let's see where you stand.

options.text: Expert - I've worked in this space for years

followUp.questionText: How do you stay open to new perspectives? Experts can have blind spots.

options.insight: BEST: Combines knowledge with learning mindset

options.text: New to this, but willing to learn quickly
Not much knowledge, will figure it out as I go
options.warning: HIGH RISK: Building without domain knowledge often fails

questions.questionText: What's ONE thing you RECENTLY LEARNED about this space that SURPRISED you?
questions.narrativeIntro: The best entrepreneurs are constantly learning. Show me you have genuine curiosity.

rubric.description: Genuine insight that changed their thinking

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate the quality of recent learning. Look for genuine curiosity, depth of insight, and how it affects their approach.

ifWeak.compoundingImpact: Builds wrong product, misses market needs, slow iteration

format.positiveSignals: List specific decisions that showed competency
format.negativeSignals: List specific decisions that showed weakness

decisionPoint.question: Based on your problem definition, are you ready to move forward?

options.text: I need to refine my problem
